title: First Scan
description: Complete your first product scan and open the passport view.
example: Scan any barcode in the demo list and view the product passport page.
learning_outcome: Understand what a product passport contains and where transparency information appears.

title: Multi-Stage
description: Find a product that has multiple supply chain stages (at least 3).
example: Open a product passport and check that it lists 3+ stages in the timeline.
learning_outcome: Recognise that products pass through multiple organisations/steps before reaching consumers.

title: Main Ingredient Origin
description: Identify the origin country of the main ingredient (highest proportion) in a product.
example: For a chocolate product, identify where the main ingredient originated.
learning_outcome: Learn to interpret ingredient composition and connect it to sourcing/ethical impact.

title: Evidence Match
description: Choose the strongest evidence to support an ethical claim
example: Pick the best evidence ordering: audit report vs supplier statement vs company webpage.
learning_outcome: Understand that not all evidence is equal; independent third party evidence is stronger.

title: Missing Evidence
description: Spot a claim that has missing or insufficient evidence attached.
example: A product says 'organic' but has no certificate/audit attached in the evidence section.
learning_outcome: Learn to identify unsupported claims and the importance of verification.

title: Weak Evidence
description: Detect when a claim is supported only by weak evidence
example: A sustainability claim is backed only by a supplier statement without third party verification.
learning_outcome: Learn why independent checks (audits/certifications) reduce greenwashing risk.

title: Wrong Evidence Type
description: Identify evidence that is the wrong type for a specific claim.
example: Using shipping manifests or batch records to 'prove' an organic claim (wrong evidence).
learning_outcome: Understand evidence relevance: different claims require specific proof types.

title: Relative Value (Most Value)
description: Find which stage contributes the most value to a product.
example: On a passport, compare stage value shares and pick the highest one.
learning_outcome: Learn how value is distributed across a supply chain and why that affects transparency priorities.

title: Relative Value (Rank Stages)
description: Rank stages from highest to lowest value contribution.
example: Given stage values like 30%, 25%, 20%, 15%, 10%, order the stage names correctly.
learning_outcome: Build intuition for where value creation happens and how to interpret value share information.

title: Value + Evidence Transparency Risk
description: Identify the biggest transparency risk: high value contribution but weak evidence support.
example: Stage A has the highest value share but only a supplier statement; flag it as highest risk.
learning_outcome: Learn to prioritise investigation: focus on high-impact stages with weak verification.
